sentences.sentence: Speaker of the US House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi should not have visited Taiwan, despite what she writes on our opinion pages today.
Her trip there highlights nothing that the world doesn't already know about China's dictatorship, and adds nothing to improve Taiwan's security from China's bullying.
The risks and consequences involving Taiwan are alarming enough as it is.
President Joe Biden, the State Department and the Pentagon all opposed her going.
But China's leaders would be as mistaken as Ms Pelosi if they now overreact - as they so often can't help doing.
This is potentially the most serious confrontation since the 1990s, when China was vastly less powerful than it is now.
Taiwan is the implicit question running through the review of Australia's defences announced by the Albanese government yesterday.
Former defence chief Angus Houston, who will lead the review, says the strategic environment is the worst in his lifetime.

Australia will now spend more on defence, looking at what can be done with our ambitious arms programs to generate more deterrent firepower sooner rather than later.Forty years of diplomatic ambiguity between the US and China on Taiwan are being stretched near breaking point.
Since 1979, Washington has officially recognised only one China.
It would only "acknowledge" China's claim on Taiwan where an anti-communist government-in-exile ruled before it turned democratic.
So long as China couldn't or didn't use the military option, that stance was never tested.
But new superpower China sees this as unfinished business, which President Xi Jinping asserts can no longer be pushed "from generation to generation".
Beijing has ramped up military harassment of Taiwan.
Washington has talked up support.

Ms Pelosi stepping onto Taiwan's soil makes President Xi look weak, just as he seeks to crown China's rise with an unprecedented third term at the helm.In China's eyes, Taiwan is also the centrepiece of the so-called first island chain, the string of bases for the supposed US containment of China's rise - the cork in the bottle of the South China Sea, as US World War II strategists once saw it.
If it's gone, America's post-1945 system unravels.
Japan's position would be untenable, and it might seek nuclear arms.
Australia would be very exposed.
America's biggest global asset - the credibility of its alliances - would evaporate.But Taiwan is more than a pawn in some great power game.
It's a miracle economy in its own right, which in the 1980s carefully transitioned from dictatorship to democracy to become a global technology powerhouse.
The chances of reaching a political settlement with China, which once seemed plausible, have faded along with the one country, two systems model in Hong Kong.
China's one-party state has proved incapable in the former British colony of running this autonomous, liberal and law-based global city with a strong civil society.
Why would 24 million Taiwanese freely choose that fate too?
Yet Vladimir Putin's quagmire in Ukraine has shown Beijing the huge risks of attempting a quick military grab of Taiwan.

Most likely is that pressure and coercion in Taiwan's sea and airspace continues below the level of actual conflict, bringing more flashpoints.Were war to break out, the consequences would be disastrous for Australia and the world.
The US-China trade lanes, the world's biggest, would collapse and send the rest of the world economy into turmoil.
Lowy Institute polling shows Australians narrowly backing an intervention by our ANZUS ally to help Taiwan.
Yet remarkable archival research by Professor James Curran, a columnist for The Australian Financial Review, shows Australia has always kept a more eyes-open view of China than Americans.

In 1980, prescient Australian officials warned that even as China gained most from joining the world trading system, it might eventually go its own way - rather than converging with the Western economic club as idealistic Americans once imagined.Washington's excessive hope has turned to alarm, helping to drive this unwanted test of wills over Ms Pelosi's visit.
The counter is that China is still too locked into global trade to bring it all down upon itself, as Mr Putin has impetuously done by turning Russia's energy trade on his own customers.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Speaker of the US House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi should not have visited Taiwan, despite what she writes on our opinion pages today. Her trip there highlights nothing that the world doesn't already know about China's dictatorship, and adds nothing to improve Taiwan's security from China's bullying. The risks and consequences involving Taiwan are alarming enough as it is. President Joe Biden, the State Department and the Pentagon all opposed her going. But China's leaders would be as mistaken as Ms Pelosi if they now overreact - as they so often can't help doing. This is potentially the most serious confrontation since the 1990s, when China was vastly less powerful than it is now. Taiwan is the implicit question running through the review of Australia's defences announced by the Albanese government yesterday. Former defence chief Angus Houston, who will lead the review, says the strategic environment is the worst in his lifetime. Australia will now spend more on defence, looking at what can be done with our ambitious arms programs to generate more deterrent firepower sooner rather than later.Forty years of diplomatic ambiguity between the US and China on Taiwan are being stretched near breaking point. Since 1979, Washington has officially recognised only one China. It would only "acknowledge" China's claim on Taiwan where an anti-communist government-in-exile ruled before it turned democratic. So long as China couldn't or didn't use the military option, that stance was never tested. But new superpower China sees this as unfinished business, which President Xi Jinping asserts can no longer be pushed "from generation to generation". Beijing has ramped up military harassment of Taiwan. Washington has talked up support. Ms Pelosi stepping onto Taiwan's soil makes President Xi look weak, just as he seeks to crown China's rise with an unprecedented third term at the helm.In China's eyes, Taiwan is also the centrepiece of the so-called first island chain, the string of bases for the supposed US containment of China's rise - the cork in the bottle of the South China Sea, as US World War II strategists once saw it. If it's gone, America's post-1945 system unravels. Japan's position would be untenable, and it might seek nuclear arms. Australia would be very exposed. America's biggest global asset - the credibility of its alliances - would evaporate.But Taiwan is more than a pawn in some great power game. It's a miracle economy in its own right, which in the 1980s carefully transitioned from dictatorship to democracy to become a global technology powerhouse. The chances of reaching a political settlement with China, which once seemed plausible, have faded along with the one country, two systems model in Hong Kong. China's one-party state has proved incapable in the former British colony of running this autonomous, liberal and law-based global city with a strong civil society. Why would 24 million Taiwanese freely choose that fate too? Yet Vladimir Putin's quagmire in Ukraine has shown Beijing the huge risks of attempting a quick military grab of Taiwan. Most likely is that pressure and coercion in Taiwan's sea and airspace continues below the level of actual conflict, bringing more flashpoints.Were war to break out, the consequences would be disastrous for Australia and the world. The US-China trade lanes, the world's biggest, would collapse and send the rest of the world economy into turmoil. Lowy Institute polling shows Australians narrowly backing an intervention by our ANZUS ally to help Taiwan. Yet remarkable archival research by Professor James Curran, a columnist for The Australian Financial Review, shows Australia has always kept a more eyes-open view of China than Americans. In 1980, prescient Australian officials warned that even as China gained most from joining the world trading system, it might eventually go its own way - rather than converging with the Western economic club as idealistic Americans once imagined.Washington's excessive hope has turned to alarm, helping to drive this unwanted test of wills over Ms Pelosi's visit. The counter is that China is still too locked into global trade to bring it all down upon itself, as Mr Putin has impetuously done by turning Russia's energy trade on his own customers.
